message_1:
Consider the topological space defined by X = {a, b, c} and τ = {∅, X, {a}, {a, b}}. 

What are the interior and closure of the set {a}?
message_2:
In the given topological space X = {a, b, c} and τ = {∅, X, {a}, {a, b}}, let's find the interior and closure of the set {a}.

Interior:
The interior of a set A is the union of all open sets contained in A. In this case, A = {a}. Since {a} is an open set (it belongs to τ), the interior of {a} is {a} itself.

Interior({a}) = {a}

Closure:
The closure of a set A is the intersection of all closed sets containing A. A set is closed if its complement (with respect to the topological space X) is open. Let's find the closed sets in this topological space.

The complements of open sets in τ are:
- X \ ∅ = X, which is closed (complement of the empty set)
- X \ X = ∅, which is closed (complement of the entire space)
- X \ {a} = {b, c}, which is closed (complement of {a})
- X \ {a, b} = {c}, which is not closed (complement of {a, b} is not in τ)

Now, we need to find the intersection of all closed sets containing {a}. The closed sets are {∅, X, {b, c}}. The sets containing {a} are {X, {b, c}}. The intersection of these sets is {a}.

Closure({a}) = {a}

So, the interior of the set {a} is {a}, and the closure of the set {a} is {a}.
